title-group.article-title: Effects of maternal clothianidin exposure on behavioral development in F1 generation mice

contrib-group.aff: Department of Environmental Health and Toxicology, Tokyo Metropolitan Institute of Public Health, Hyakunincho, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Toyohito Tanaka, Department of Environmental Health and Toxicology, Tokyo Metropolitan Institute of Public Health, 3-24-1, Hyakunincho, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169-0073, Japan Email: t-tanaka@poohlover.net

abstract.p: Female mice were exposed maternally to clothianidin through diet at levels of 0% (control), 0.002%, 0.006%, and 0.018% during gestation and lactation periods. Selected reproductive and neurobehavioral parameters were measured in F1 generation. There was no adverse effect of clothianidin on litter size, litter weight, or sex ratio at birth. The average body weight of male and female offspring was increased significantly in a dose-related manner during the lactation period. With respect to behavioral developmental parameters, surface righting at postnatal day 7 of female offspring was accelerated significantly in a dose-related manner (p < 0.05). For movement activity of exploratory behavior at 3 weeks of age, the average speed (cm/s) of male offspring increased significantly in a dose-related manner (p < 0.05). With regard to spontaneous behavior in the F1 generation, males showed more activity in some measured variables in the middle-dose group. The dose levels of clothianidin in the present study produced several adverse effects in the neurobehavioral parameters in mice.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Clothianidin, (E)-1-(2-chloro-1,3-thiazol-5-ylmethyl)-3-methyl-2-nitroguanidine is a neonicotinoid insecticide available as water-soluble powders, wettable powders, granules, and dusts. It is a broad-spectrum systemic insecticide and is effective on insect pest species such as hemipterans, thysanopterans, orthopterans, coleopterans, lepidopterans, dipterans, hymenopterans, and isopterans (Uneme et al., 2006). Clothianidin is registered for agricultural use on various fruits, vegetables, forage, and grain crops. Its permitted residue levels are 0.7 ppm in unpolished rice, 0.02 ppm in other grain crops, 0.1 ppm in soybeans, 0.02 ppm in peanuts, 0.3 ppm in other legumes, 0.3–5 ppm in drupes, 1–2 ppm in citrus fruits, 1 ppm in pome fruits, 0.02–1 ppm in tropical fruits, 0.02–0.7 ppm in berry fruits, 0.02–5 ppm in cruciferous vegetables, 0.02–0.25 ppm in potatoes, 0.02–2 ppm in cucurbitaceous vegetables, 0.02–20 ppm in composite vegetables, 0.02 ppm in fungi, 0.02–5 ppm in dropwort vegetables, 1–3 ppm in solanaceous vegetables, 0.02–15 ppm in liliaceous vegetables, 0.02–2 ppm in other vegetables, 0.01–0.02 ppm in oil seeds, 0.02 ppm in nuts and cocoa beans, 0.04 ppm in coffee beans, 50 ppm in tea leaves, and 0.02 ppm in cattle, goat, hog, horse, sheep, and poultry in Japan (Food Hygienic Society of Japan, 2008). Clothianidin is used for expelling termites in housing. The acceptable daily intake (ADI) for humans has been set at 0.097 mg/kg body weight (bw) in Japan (Japan Food Safety Commission, 2008).

In toxicological studies of clothianidin (Sumitomo Chemical Takeda Agro Company, Ltd, 2003), its oral and dermal median lethal dose (LD50) in rats exceeded 5000 mg/kg bw and 2000 mg/kg bw, respectively. The oral LD50 in male and female mice was 389 mg/kg bw and 465 mg/kg bw, respectively. In 90-day oral toxicity studies, the nonobserved adverse effect level (NOAEL) was 500 ppm in male and female rats (approximately 27.9 mg/kg bw/day and 34.0 mg/kg bw/day, respectively), and the corresponding value in male and female dogs was 650 ppm (approximately 19.3 mg/kg bw/day and 21.2 mg/kg bw/day, respectively). In a chronic and carcinogenic study in rats, it showed no carcinogenic effects, and NOAELs in male and female rats were 500 ppm (approximately 27.4 mg/kg bw/day) and 150 ppm (approximately 9.7 mg/kg bw/day), respectively. It produced no carcinogenic effects in mice, and NOAEL in male and female mice was 350 ppm (approximately 47.2 mg/kg bw/day and 65.1 mg/kg bw/day, respectively).

With respect to reproductive and developmental toxicity studies (Sumitomo Chemical Takeda Agro Company, Ltd, 2003), clothianidin showed no teratogenicity after administration on days 6–19 of gestation in rats (10–125 mg/kg bw/day) and NOAELs were 10 mg/kg bw/day in maternal effects (decrease in body weight gain and food consumption) and 125 mg/kg bw/day in fetal effects (no effects). It also showed no teratogenicity in administration on days 6–28 of gestation in rabbits (10–100 mg/kg bw/day), and NOAELs were 10 mg/kg bw/day in maternal effects (decrease in defecation, colored urine, or maternal death) and 25 mg/kg bw/day in fetal effects (fetal death, decrease in fetal weight, or ossifying delay in sternebrae). In a two-generation toxicity study in rats, clothianidin produced no adverse effects in reproduction, and its NOAELs in male and female rats were 150 ppm in parental effects (approximately 9.8 mg/kg bw/day and 11.5 mg/kg bw/day, respectively) and 150 ppm in offspring effects (approximately 10.7 mg/kg bw/day and 12.2 mg/kg bw/day, respectively).

In neurotoxicity studies in rats (EPA, 2003), clothianidin (>100 mg/kg) decreased arousal, motor, and locomotor activities in the acute neurotoxicity study. In a subchronic neurotoxicity study, it had no adverse effects in neurotoxicity, and its NOAELs in male and female rats were 60.0 mg/kg bw/day and 71.0 mg/kg bw/day, respectively. It produced no adverse effects in the developmental neurotoxicity study, and its NOAELs were 42.9 mg/kg bw/day in maternal effects and 12.9 mg/kg bw/day in offspring effects.
The present study was designed to evaluate the neurobehavioral effects of maternal clothianidin exposure, including measurement of spontaneous behavior, in mice of different generations.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Clothianidin was obtained from Wako Pure Chemical Industries Ltd (Tokyo, Japan; Lot No. DPJ8171). The chemical characterization was “clothianidin standard for residual pesticide analysis,” and the purity was >99.0%. The chemical stability of clothianidin is >12 months at 25°C and >6 months at 40°C (Uneme et al., 2006).

sec.title: Animals and maintenance
sec.p: Male and female mice (Crlj: CD1, 4 weeks of age) were purchased from Charles River Japan Inc (Kanagawa, Japan). They were housed individually in polycarbonate solid-floored cages with wood flakes and kept in a temperature-controlled room maintained at 25 ± 1°C at a relative humidity of 50 ± 5% on a 12-h light/dark cycle. They were given control diets and water ad libitum from 4 weeks of age to mating in the F0 generation and after weaning in the F1 generation. Dams were given control or experimental diets and water ad libitum during the gestation and lactation periods.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: Clothianidin was administered through diet to 30 female mice (10 per group) at dietary levels of 0.002%, 0.006%, and 0.018%, during the gestation and lactation periods in the F0 generation. The control group (10 female mice) was given basal diets (CE-2; Nihon Clea, Tokyo, Japan) for the corresponding time period. Experimental diets were prepared bimonthly (twice) in our laboratory. After mixing clothianidin with the powdered diet, pellets were formed and fed to mice. The stability of clothianidin was not tested in the pellets during the experimental period. The homogeneity of the test compound was ensured by the preparation procedures of the experimental diets in our laboratory when previously measured by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). The concentration and homogeneity of the test compound in the diet were not tested during the experimental period. Individual food intake of mice was measured during the following three periods: gestation (14 days), lactation (from birth to weaning), and F1 generation (4 weeks to 11 weeks of age). Individual food intake (g/kg bw/day) was calculated as (the difference in feed weight between the previous and present week excepting the fallen lumps weight in cage)/(average body weight between the previous and present week)/days.

sec.title: Reproductive procedure
sec.p: Mice from the F0 generation were 5 weeks of age at the start of the study. They were weighed individually on experimental days 0, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 30, during the preconception period. At 9 weeks of age, each female was paired with one male for 5 days. The females were examined for mating by appearance of the vaginal plug twice a day (morning and evening). The males were separated from females after 5 days. The females were then allowed to carry their litters to term, deliver, and rear all of their offspring. After mating, the dams were assigned to the groups by the stratified randomization method and given control or experimental diets during the gestation and lactation periods. The dams were weighed individually during the gestation (every day on weekdays) and lactation periods (once a week). The dams were examined for delivery at three times a day (morning, early afternoon, and evening).

At birth, live and dead offspring was counted and litter size, litter weight, and sex ratio (male:female) of live offspring were measured on postnatal day (PND) 0. Litter was not culled and all offspring were examined for test procedure. Offspring were individually weighed on PNDs 0, 4, 7, 14, and 21 during the lactation period. The survival indices were calculated as follows: (live offspring at each period)/(live and dead offspring at birth) × 100(%). Offspring were weaned when they were 4 weeks of age. One male and one female were randomly selected to continue treatment from each litter. Mice were weighed every week from 4 weeks to 11 weeks of age after weaning.

sec.title: Procedure for measuring neurobehavioral parameters
sec.p: Functional and behavioral developmental parameters were measured and scored for all individual offspring during the lactation period in the F1 generation (Tanaka et al., 1992) and analyzed on score frequencies (Tanaka, 1995). All offspring were examined for behavioral development during the lactation period. The measured parameters were as detailed below.

sec.title: Surface righting on PNDs 4 and 7
sec.p: Offspring were placed on their backs on a smooth surface, and the time required to right themselves to a position where all four limbs touched the surface was recorded (Fox, 1965; Pantaleoni et al., 1988). The following scoring system was employed for successful righting: 2 = righting within 1 s; 1 = righting in >1 s but within 2 s; and 0 = righting in >2 s.

sec.title: Negative geotaxis on PNDs 4 and 7
sec.p: Offspring were placed in a head down position on a plane inclined at 30° and the time required to reorient to a head up position was recorded (Altman and Sudarshan, 1975; Fox, 1965; Pantaleoni et al., 1988). The plane was made of plywood covered with sandpaper (fine grade). The following scoring system was employed: 0 = no response within 60 s; 1 = response within 60 s; and 2 = response within 30 s.

sec.title: Cliff avoidance on PND 7
sec.p: Offspring were placed on a platform elevated 10 cm above a tabletop (Altman and Sudarshan, 1975; Fox, 1965; Pantaleoni et al., 1988). Forelimbs and snout were positioned such that the edge of the platform passed just behind an imaginary line drawn between the eye orbits. The following scoring system was employed: 0 = no response within 20 s; 1 = avoided backwards within 20 s; and 2 = avoiding with turn.

sec.title: Swimming behavior on PNDs 7 and 14
sec.p: Offspring were placed in a tank with water temperature maintained at 23 ± 1°C (Fox, 1965; Pantaleoni et al., 1988). Swimming behavior was rated for direction (3 = straight; 2 = circling; and 1 = floating) and head angle (4 = ears out of water; 3 = ears half out of water; 2 = nose and top of head out of water; and 1 = unable to hold head up). Limb movement was rated as 1 = all four limbs used and 2 = only hind limbs used.

sec.title: Olfactory orientation on PND 14
sec.p: Offspring were placed into an arm connecting two compartments (Altman and Sudarshan, 1975; Barlow et al., 1978; Meyer and Hansen, 1980). One compartment was covered with “home” wood flakes (i.e., from their cages) and the other was covered with “fresh” wood flakes. The time required to enter the compartment with the home wood flakes was recorded. Olfactory orientation was scored for time taken (3 = entered the home wood flakes compartment within 30 s; 2 = entered within 60 s; 1 = entered within 90 s; and 0 = no response within 90 s) and for route (1 = entered the home wood flakes compartment via the fresh wood flakes compartment and 2 = entered the home wood flakes compartment directly).

The exploratory behavior of mice was measured in the animal movement analysis system SCANET CV-40 (Melquest Ltd, Toyama, Japan) on distance (DT) mode at 3 weeks and 8 weeks of age in the F1 generation. The system consisted of a rectangular cage (300 × 202 × 205 mm3) made from acrylate resins with two crossing sensor frames of 72 units of detectors of near-infrared photosensors for measuring spontaneous motor activity (Mikami et al., 2002). The behavioral parameters were recorded for 10 min on one male and one female mouse selected randomly from each litter at 3 weeks of age and on all mice at 8 weeks of age in the F1 generation. The measurement parameters on DT mode were as follows: total distance (cm), number of horizontal activities, movement time (s), number of rearing, rearing time (s), average time of movement (s), average speed (cm/s), average time of rearing (s), and number of defecations.

Each mouse underwent one trial per day for 3 days in a Biel-type multiple-T water maze adapted for mice at 7 weeks of age in the F1 generation (Biel, 1940; Kitatani et al., 1988). Water temperature was maintained at 20 ± 1°C. The time taken and number of errors were measured from the start to finish for a maximum of 120 s. If the time taken was >120 s, it was recorded as 120 s (Kitatani et al., 1988).

The spontaneous behavior of mice was measured in the animal movement analyzing system SCANET CV-40 (Melquest Ltd) on DT mode from 9 weeks to 10 weeks of age in the F1 generation. The behavioral parameters were measured on all mice for 120 min at an interval of 10 min after 10-min latency. The measurement parameters were the same as those for exploratory behavior except for the number of defecations.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Food intake, litter size, litter weight, and body weight were assessed with Bonferroni’s multiple comparison test after the analysis of variance (ANOVA) or the Kruskal–Wallis test. Sex ratio, survival, and behavioral developmental data were assessed with the χ2 test or the Fisher’s exact test of frequency analysis. Exploratory behavior data were assessed with the Steel–Dwass test of nonparametric methods (Martin and Bateson, 1990). In spontaneous behavior data, the longitudinal pattern was assessed with the profile analysis in the parallelism hypothesis test, and variables at each point of time were assessed with the Steel–Dwass test within each treatment group. Multiple-T water maze performance data were assessed with the Sign–Wilcoxon test for trials and assessed with the Steel–Dwass test within each treatment group. Dose–response effects were assessed with the Jonckheere test for ordered alternatives or the cumulative χ2 test (multi) for frequency data.

sec.title: Guidelines
sec.p: The design of the present study was based on the guidelines issued by ICH (2005) and OECD (2007) adapted for mice. In our institute, mice are usually employed in reproductive and neurobehavioral toxicity studies to conserve resources (chemicals, diets, space, etc.) and background data for mice are sufficient for the evaluation of neurobehavioral effects (Tanaka, 2004). We conducted the present study in accordance with the guidelines set by The Science Council of Japan (2006).

sec.title: Intake of food and chemicals
sec.p: There was no difference (p < 0.05) related to the treatment of clothianidin on the average intake of food during any period. The average intake of chemicals was increased consistently in a dose-related manner during the gestation and lactation periods (Table 1).

caption.p: Average daily food and chemical intake of mice administered clothianidin in a maternal-exposure studya

fn.p: aEach value represents daily intake during each period (mean ± SD).

sec.title: F0 generation
sec.p: The average body weight of female mice showed no difference (p < 0.05) with respect to treatment during the gestation and lactation periods. Two females did not become pregnant in the control group. One dam killed her litter in the low-dose group during the first week (day 0) of the lactation period. One dam each of the middle- and high-dose groups died during the second week (days 14 and 13, respectively) of the lactation period. One dam of the control group died during the third week (day 15) of the lactation period. The cause of these dams’ death was uncertain since unclear change to a morbid state was admitted.

sec.title: F1 generation
sec.p: At birth, no difference (p < 0.05) related to the treatment was observed in litter size, litter weight, or sex ratio (Table 2). Although there is no significant effect, the female offspring outnumbered the male offspring only in the 0.018% group. The average body weight at birth was increased significantly in female offspring of the middle-dose group. The average body weight of male offspring was increased significantly in all treatment groups at PNDs 4 and 21, and in the high-dose groups at PND 7 (Table 3), and it showed a significantly dose-related increase at PNDs 4, 7, and 21 (p < 0.05 in each) during the lactation period in the trend test. The average body weight of female offspring was increased significantly in all treatment groups at PNDs 4, 7, and 21 and in the middle-dose group at PND 14 (Table 3), and it showed a significantly dose-related increase at PNDs 4, 7, 14, and 21 (p < 0.01, p < 0.01, p < 0.05, and p < 0.01, respectively) during the lactation period in the trend test. One litter each of the middle- and high-dose groups was euthanized (to prevent them dying of starvation) at PNDs 15 and 13, respectively, in view of the death of the dam during the second week of the lactation period. The survival indices, which were calculated excluding the killed litters, showed no difference (p < 0.05) related to the treatment during the lactation period in either sex (Table 4).

caption.p: Summary of data of litters at birth in a maternal-exposure study of clothianidin administered to micea

fn.p: aEach value represents the mean ± SD.

caption.p: Summary of average body weight (g) of offspring during the lactation period in F1 generation mice in a maternal-exposure study of clothianidin administered to micea

fn.p: aEach value represents the mean ± SD. Significantly different from controls.

caption.p: Summary of ratio of live offspring and survival index (%) during the lactation period in a maternal-exposure study of clothianidin administered to micea

fn.p: aEach value represents ratio of live offspring and survival index (%) in parentheses. Survival indices ((live offspring at each period)/(live and dead offspring at birth) × 100 (%)) are calculated except for the dead litters at each period.

sec.p: With respect to behavioral developmental parameters, surface righting at PND 7 was accelerated significantly in the low-dose group in female offspring (Figure 1), and this effect was significantly dose related (p < 0.05). The development of swimming direction was accelerated significantly in the middle-dose group in female offspring at PND 7 (Figure 1). The time taken for olfactory orientation at PND 14 was accelerated significantly in the middle-dose groups in female offspring (Figure 1). Other variables showed no difference (p < 0.05) related to the treatment in either sex. For the movement activity of exploratory behavior at 3 weeks of age, the average speed (cm/s) of male offspring increased significantly in a dose-related manner (p < 0.05) in the trend test (Figure 2).

caption.p: Score frequencies for behavioral development in the lactation period in a maternal-exposure study of clothianidin administered to mice. Significantly different from controls, *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01.

Movement activity of exploratory behavior at 3 weeks of age in F1 generation male mice in a maternal-exposure study of clothianidin administered to mice. Each value represents the mean ± standard error. Average speed (cm/s) showed significantly dose-related characteristics in a trend test (p < 0.05).

sec.p: There was no difference (p < 0.05) related to the treatment with clothianidin on multiple-T water maze performance at 7 weeks of age in either sex. In the movement activity of exploratory behavior at 8 weeks of age, the average time of rearing (s) of females decreased significantly in the middle-dose group (Figure 3). For the movement activity of spontaneous behavior from 9 weeks to 10 weeks of age in the F1 generation, all variables measured in each sex were parallel in a longitudinal pattern. In males, total distance (cm), number of horizontal activities, movement time (s), average speed (cm/s), average time of movement (s), rearing time (s), and average time of rearing (s) were significantly active at and after 100 min in the middle-dose group (Figure 4). In females, there was no difference (p < 0.05) related to the treatment with clothianidin on any variables measured. The average body weight of male and female mice showed no difference (p < 0.05) related to the treatment after weaning.

caption.p: Movement activity of exploratory behavior at 8 weeks of age in F1 generation female mice in a maternal exposure study of clothianidin administered to mice. Each value represents the mean ± standard error. Significantly different from controls, *p < 0.05.

Movement activity of spontaneous behavior from 9 weeks to 10 weeks of age of F1 generation male mice in a maternal-exposure study of clothianidin administered to mice. Each value represents the mean ± standard error. Significantly different from controls, *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, clothianidin produced some significant effects on reproductive and neurobehavioral parameters. The female offspring outnumbered the male offspring only in the 0.018% group (sex ratio: 0.75). However, Tanaka (2001, 2005) reported that the females sometimes outnumbered the males in control mice (sex ratio: <0.75). It seems, therefore, that the effect on sex ratio is not caused by clothianidin treatment. The average body weight of male and female offspring showed a slightly dose-related acceleration during the lactation period in the trend test. Survival indices during the lactation period showed no significant difference between the control and treatment groups, and the average litter size during the lactation period for each group was similar. There was no difference related to the treatment with clothianidin on average food intake of dams during the gestation and lactation periods. The average body weight of dams showed no difference related to the treatment during the gestation and lactation periods. Therefore, these changes in offspring weight may have been caused by clothianidin treatment because offspring consumed similar nourishment in each group.

For the behavioral developmental parameters, surface righting in female offspring showed a significant tendency to be accelerated in treatment groups at PND 7. Therefore, it seems that the dose levels of clothianidin produced influences on surface righting, indicative of development of coordinated movement, in female offspring during the early lactation period. Swimming direction at PND 7 and time taken for olfactory orientation at PND 14 showed a significant acceleration in the middle-dose group. These influences may have been caused by increased body weights in treatment groups because the body weight of female offspring showed a significantly dose-related acceleration during the lactation period. Nevertheless, male offspring showed no influence on behavioral development during the lactation period. Tanaka (2004) reported that behavioral developments during the lactation period were not influenced by offspring weight under natural conditions. Therefore, it seems that the dose levels of clothianidin produced influences on these variables of behavioral development in female offspring during the lactation period.

For movement activity, the average speed (cm/s) of male offspring showed a significant tendency to be increased in treatment groups for exploratory behavior in the F1 generation. In adult females, the average time of rearing (s) showed a significant depression in the middle-dose group for exploratory behavior in the F1 generation. For spontaneous behavior of the F1 generation, total distance (cm), number of horizontal activities, movement time (s), average speed (cm/s), average time of movement (s), rearing time (s), and average time of rearing (s) were significantly active at and after 100 min in the middle-dose group in adult males. Nevertheless, there was no difference related to the treatment with clothianidin on any variables in adult females. Therefore, it seems that the middle dose of clothianidin produced more activities for spontaneous behavior in adult male mice of the F1 generation. The effects of clothianidin on the central nervous system may cause these changes on movement activities because clothianidin was observed to be concentrated in the brain after oral and intravenous administration in rats (Yokota et al., 2003). These effects on exploratory and spontaneous behavior after weaning may be caused by the irreversible changes in the central nervous system because clothianidin treatment was stopped at weaning.

In the F1 generation, a few variables of exploratory behavior for a novel environment showed a slight tendency to be active in treatment groups in male offspring and showed a significant depression in the middle-dose group of adult females. The spontaneous behavior was significantly active in the middle-dose group in adult male mice of the F1 generation. Therefore, it seems that sensitivity for clothianidin is dependent on sex in mice. The dose levels of clothianidin in the present study produced several adverse effects on neurobehavioral parameters in mice. The middle dose of clothianidin produced significant adverse effects on exploratory and spontaneous behavior in F1 generation mice. The middle-dose level (equivalent to 9–33 mg/kg bw/day) was based on the current ADI of clothianidin (0.097 mg/kg bw). The estimated daily intake of clothianidin is presumed to be much lower, approximately 3.91 μg/kg bw/day in the national average, 6.65 μg/kg bw/day in infants (1–6 years of age), 3.38 μg/kg bw/day in pregnant women, and 4.05 μg/kg bw/day in senior citizens (>65 years of age), in Japan (Japan Food Safety Commission, 2008). Therefore, it would appear that the levels of the dietary intake of clothianidin are unlikely to produce adverse effects in humans.

fn.label: Conflict of interest
fn.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
